Denk T.	"Palaeoecological interpretation of the late Miocene landscapes and vegetation of northern Greece: A comment to Merceron et al., 2016 (Geobios 49, 135?146)"	2016	Geobios	49	6		423	431			1	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.009	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85001086075&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.009&partnerID=40&md5=1375154fcc089d7df41dadafe50d4afb	"Swedish Museum of Natural History, Department of Palaeobiology, Box 50007, Stockholm, Sweden"	"Denk, T., Swedish Museum of Natural History, Department of Palaeobiology, Box 50007, Stockholm, Sweden"	"Recent works on feeding habits of ungulates, isotopic composition of equid tooth enamel, and phytoliths from late Miocene localities of northern Greece suggested the presence of savannah and excluded dense forests. Furthermore, Mediterranean-like climates were advocated for the late Miocene of Greece. Here, I compare palaeoenvironments inferred for two mammal localities from Chalkidiki and the Axios Valley (Nikiti, upper Vallesian and lower Turolian; Dytiko, upper Turolian) with evidence from contemporaneous plant assemblages from adjacent areas in Greece and Bulgaria. I use vegetation units inferred from pollen and spore, fruit and seed, and leaf assemblages and compare them with the vegetation inferred from mammal and phytolith data. Open vegetation as inferred from mammal and phytolith data is also part of the range of vegetation units discovered from the pollen and spore, seed and fruit, and leaf record (here called the palaeobotanical record). Poaceae are consistently present in late Vallesian to late Turolian pollen records of northern Greece. Further, a number of vegetation units are indicative of forest vegetation ranging from lowland to upland forests dominated by woody angiosperms and mixed coniferous-angiosperm forests. The presence of such forests is not in conflict with the results from mammal and phytolith studies, but it broadens the view on landscapes present in the late Miocene of northern Greece. In addition to a generalized vegetation type commonly inferred by mammal studies, the palaeobotanical record demonstrates the presence of various complementary vegetation types. A comprehensive view on late Miocene landscapes in northern Greece shows that there is no conflict in inferring open herb dominated landscapes and light to dense forests and provides new opportunities for the ecological interpretation of late Miocene ungulates. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Forest; Hipparion faunas; Landscape definition; Open landscape; Plant fossils; Scale	fauna; fossil record; landscape; mammal; Miocene; paleoecology; paleoenvironment; palynology; plant; savanna; vegetation type; Bulgaria; Greece; Equidae; Hipparion; Magnoliophyta; Mammalia; Poaceae; Ungulata; Vallesia					"VR, Vetenskapsr?det; VR, Vetenskapsr?det"	This study was funded by a grant from the Swedish Research Council (VR). Comments by Zlatko Kva?ek and Jean-Pierre Suc considerably improved the manuscript. "Lu J., Chen X."	New insights into the base of the Emsian (Lower Devonian) in South China	2016	Geobios	49	6		459	467		lujfivan@sina.cn	1	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.09.003	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85001103498&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.09.003&partnerID=40&md5=219c06652e6f0a451f067c2434b56268	"Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 39, East Beijing Road, Nanjing, China; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China"	"Lu, J., Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 39, East Beijing Road, Nanjing, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Chen, X., Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 39, East Beijing Road, Nanjing, China"	"Traditionally, the lower boundary of the Emsian (Lower Devonian) has been defined as the base of the dehiscens Zone marked by the first entry of the conodont Polygnathus dehiscens. However, following taxonomic revision of P. dehiscens, the current practice is to use the first appearance of P. kitabicus to define the base of the Emsian. As a result, specimens previously identified as P. dehiscens from South China need to be thoroughly reviewed. Careful examination of the oral and aboral features of the platform reveal that most specimens previously described as P. dehiscens from nine sections in Guangxi and Yunnan actually refer to P. excavatus excavatus or P. excavatus ssp. 114. In the South China Block, widespread and massive deposition of Devonian carbonates began during the time of the excavatus Zone, whereas the kitabicus Zone is probably located in the underlying strata, which mainly comprise marine siliciclastic rocks. Thus, the precise level of the lower boundary of the Emsian in South China is still unknown. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Conodont; Emsian; Polygnathus dehiscens; Polygnathus excavatus; Polygnathus kitabicus; South China	biostratigraphy; conodont; Emsian; stratigraphic boundary; taxonomy; China; Polygnathus					"PKU, Peking University; CUGB, China University of Geosciences, Beijing; 41272009, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41290260, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China"	"The manuscript was read critically by Carlos Mart?nez-P?rez and four other anonymous reviewers, as well as by Geobios Associate-Editor Catherine Girard. They provided many important and useful comments, from which we profited considerably. We also thank Changmin Yu and Wenkun Qie (Nanjing Institute of Geology and Paleontology) and Jiangsi Liu (China University of Geosciences, Wuhan) for their assistances in the field and laboratory. We are grateful to Chengyuan Wang (Nanjing Institute of Geology and Paleontology) for meaningful discussion and generosity in providing unpublished specimens. The authors sincerely thank Yuanlin Sun and his students Wen Guo and Ting Nie (Peking University) for the kind help during our time in Beijing. This study is funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (41272009, 41290260)." "Vachard D., C?zar P., Aretz M., Izart A."	Late Vis?an?Serpukhovian foraminifers in the Montagne Noire (France): Biostratigraphic revision and correlation with the Russian substages	2016	Geobios	49	6		469	498			5	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.09.002	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85000963988&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.09.002&partnerID=40&md5=c641bf1a71eccd93b1dab20f3133023d	"1, rue des Tilleuls, Gruson, France; Instituto de Geociencias CSIC-UCM, Ciudad Universitaria, Madrid, Spain; G?osciences Environnement Toulouse (GET), Observatoire Midi-Pyr?n?es, Universit? de Toulouse, CNRS, IRD, 14 avenue E. Belin, Toulouse, France; 202 Chemin de Cabanis, Prades-le-Lez, France"	"Vachard, D., 1, rue des Tilleuls, Gruson, France; C?zar, P., Instituto de Geociencias CSIC-UCM, Ciudad Universitaria, Madrid, Spain; Aretz, M., G?osciences Environnement Toulouse (GET), Observatoire Midi-Pyr?n?es, Universit? de Toulouse, CNRS, IRD, 14 avenue E. Belin, Toulouse, France; Izart, A., 202 Chemin de Cabanis, Prades-le-Lez, France"	"The ?calcaires ? Productus? of the Montagne Noire (Aude-H?rault, southern France) are carbonate lenses embedded within a thick Carboniferous siliciclastic complex. Foraminiferal assemblages in some of the larger carbonate lenses are typically representative of the late Vis?an and Serpukhovian. Eleven new species of foraminifers are described: Hemidiscopsis variabilis, H. pilleae, Planohowchinia rara, P. redondensis, Spireitlina minima, Rectoendothyra japhetensis, Mikhailovella enormis, Cribrospira? perretae, Pojarkovella occidentalis, Parabiseriella vailhanensis, and Biseriella delicata. Eight foraminiferal biozones are defined; they are based on the first occurrence of some taxa, and could be used for other regions of southern France (e.g., Mouthoumet and the Pyrenees). These biozones are informally named as A to H. Due to the problems with classical biozonations and substages in northern England as well as Belgium and northern France, the biozones established herein are mostly compared with the Russian standard substages. Thus, biozones A and B are correlated with the Mikhailovian, corresponding to the latest Asbian and earliest Brigantian in western Europe; biozones C, D and E are correlated with the Venevian, equivalent to the upper part of the early Brigantian in western Europe. Therefore, biozones A?E form part of the late and latest Vis?an. The stratigraphically younger biozones F, G and H contain foraminiferal assemblages correlated with the Tarusian, Steshevian and Protvian, respectively. ? 2016"	Biostratigraphy; Foraminifers; Late Vis?an; Mississippian; Montagne Noire; Serpukhovian; Systematics	biostratigraphy; biozonation; carbonate; foraminifera; fossil assemblage; Serpukhovian; Visean; France; Montagne Noire; Foraminifera					"CGL2012-30922BTE, MINECO, Ministerio de Econom?a y Competitividad"	"Fieldwork of D.V. and P.C. was funded by the Spanish Ministerio de Econom?a y Competitividad (research project CGL2012-30922BTE). We thank the reviewers, I. D. Somerville and R. Rettori, for their constructive comments on the manuscript."																			
"Georgalis G.L., Villa A., Vlachos E., Delfino M."	"Fossil amphibians and reptiles from Plakias, Crete: A glimpse into the earliest late Miocene herpetofaunas of southeastern Europe"	2016	Geobios	49	6		433	444		dimetrodon82@gmail.com	3	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.09.004	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85001079064&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.09.004&partnerID=40&md5=f50bff3dcb4647c7c5a9b3fdfa9f0f6d	"Department of Geosciences, University of Fribourg/Freiburg, Chemin du Mus?e 6, Fribourg, Switzerland; Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Universit? di Torino, Via Valperga Caluso 35, Torino, Italy; CONICET and Museo Paleontologico Egidio Feruglio, Av. Fontana 140, Trelew, Chubut, Argentina; School of Geology, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, University Campus, Thessaloniki, Greece; Institut Catal? de Paleontologia Miquel Crusafont, Universitat Aut?noma de Barcelona, (UAB), Edifici Z, Carrer de les Columnes s/n, Campus de la UAB, Cerdanyola del Vall?s, Barcelona, Spain"	"Georgalis, G.L., Department of Geosciences, University of Fribourg/Freiburg, Chemin du Mus?e 6, Fribourg, Switzerland, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Universit? di Torino, Via Valperga Caluso 35, Torino, Italy; Villa, A., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Universit? di Torino, Via Valperga Caluso 35, Torino, Italy; Vlachos, E., CONICET and Museo Paleontologico Egidio Feruglio, Av. Fontana 140, Trelew, Chubut, Argentina, School of Geology, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, University Campus, Thessaloniki, Greece; Delfino, M., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Universit? di Torino, Via Valperga Caluso 35, Torino, Italy, Institut Catal? de Paleontologia Miquel Crusafont, Universitat Aut?noma de Barcelona, (UAB), Edifici Z, Carrer de les Columnes s/n, Campus de la UAB, Cerdanyola del Vall?s, Barcelona, Spain"	"Fossil amphibians and reptiles from the earliest late Miocene (early Tortonian, MN 9) of Plakias (Crete, Greece) are described in this paper. Most of the material is fragmentary, precluding precise taxonomic assignment. Nevertheless, the herpetofauna of Plakias is here shown to be diverse, comprising at least six different taxa: an alytid anuran, a crocodilian, two turtles (a pan-trionychid and a geoemydid) and two squamates (an amphisbaenian and a colubroid snake). The crocodilian material represents the first such fossils described from Greece and furthermore, one of the latest occurrences of this group in Europe. The pan-trionychid and the geoemydid represent the oldest occurrences of these groups in Greece and further add to their scarce Miocene record from this country. The first description of a fossil amphisbaenian from Greece is also provided. The new specimens from Plakias add to our knowledge of the Miocene herpetofaunas of southeastern Europe. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Amphisbaenia; Anura; Crocodylia; Greece; Miocene; Serpentes; Testudines	amphibian; fossil; herpetofauna; Miocene; new species; species occurrence; turtle; Aegean Islands; Crete [Greece]; Greece; Amphibia; Amphisbaenia; Anura; Colubroidea; Crocodylidae (all crocodiles); Geoemydidae; Reptilia; Serpentes; Squamata; Testudines; Trionychidae					"AT-TAF-5911; Aristotle University of Thessaloniki; 2014 SGR 416 GRC, Generalitat de Catalunya; University of Patras; Universit? de Fribourg; ES-TAF-5910; Paris, UB, Universitatea din Bucure?ti; NHM, Natural History Museum; UoC, University of Crete"	"Wilma Wessels and Hans de Bruijn (University of Utrecht) are thanked for the long term loan of the material utilized in this study. Moysis Mylonas and Charalampos Fassoulas (Natural History Museum of Crete and University of Crete) provided access to the turtle material to EV. We also thank Walter Joyce (University of Fribourg), Borja Sanchiz (Museum of Natural Sciences, Madrid), George Iliopoulos (University of Patras), Dimitris Kostopoulos (Aristotle University of Thessaloniki) and George Koufos (Aristotle University of Thessaloniki), as also our reviewers Stefan Vasile (University of Bucharest), Johannes M?ller (Museum f?r Naturkunde, Berlin) and Jean-Claude Rage (Mus?um national d?Histoire Naturelle, Paris), and editors Gilles Escarguel (University of Lyon) and Gildas Merceron (University of Poitiers), for valuable comments that improved the quality of the manuscript. Study of snake skeletons that were used for comparisons in this study was funded by SYNTHESYS ES-TAF-5910 ( Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales , Madrid) and SYNTHESYS AT-TAF-5911 ( Naturhistorisches Museum , Vienna) grants to GLG, and the curators of these institutions, respectively, Marta Calvo-Revuelta and Heinz Grillitsch, are also acknowledged here. GLG acknowledges travel support from the University of Fribourg. Work is supported by Fondi di Ateneo dell?Universit? di Torino (2013?2014) and Generalitat de Catalunya (2014 SGR 416 GRC)." Parsons Academic Press London, New York"	"Georgalis, G.L.; Department of Geosciences, University of Fribourg/Freiburg, Chemin du Mus?e 6, Switzerland; email: dimetrodon82@gmail.com"			Elsevier Masson SAS					166995				English	Geobios	Article		Scopus	2-s2.0-85001079064
Geraads D.	"Pleistocene Carnivora (Mammalia) from Tighennif (Ternifine), Algeria"	2016	Geobios	49	6		445	458			1	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.09.001	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-85000983759&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.09.001&partnerID=40&md5=35b60bdca654ce6765b30d79235948c8	"Centre de Recherche sur la Pal?obiodiversit? et les Pal?oenvironnements (UMR 7207), Sorbonne Universit?s, MNHN, CNRS, UPMC, CP 38, 8 rue Buffon, Cedex 05, Paris, France"	"Geraads, D., Centre de Recherche sur la Pal?obiodiversit? et les Pal?oenvironnements (UMR 7207), Sorbonne Universit?s, MNHN, CNRS, UPMC, CP 38, 8 rue Buffon, Cedex 05, Paris, France"	"The site of Tighennif (= Ternifine) in Northern Algeria, well-known for its Homo mauritanicus (= Homo rhodesiensis?) remains, and probably dating to the late Calabrian, yielded a large assemblage of terrestrial carnivores. Some are identical or probably identical with extant species: Crocuta crocuta and Hyaena hyaena (Hyaenidae), Felis silvestris (Felidae), Mellivora capensis and Poecilictis cf. libyca (Mustelidae), and Vulpes cf. rueppelli (Canidae). In addition, among felids there is an unidentified leopard-like form; a smaller, more common species assigned to Lynx sp. (a genus quite rare in Africa) but which is certainly different from modern forms, an Homotherium that seems to be the last occurrence of the machairodonts in Africa, and a Panthera aff. leo, which is unfortunately too poorly known to be named. Rare bears do not display all derived features of later North African U. bibersoni. Among canids, the Nyctereutes-like jackal Lupulella mohibi is an endemic North African form known until the late middle Pleistocene, and the hunting dog Lycaon magnus is also clearly distinct from the modern species. A single new species is described, Enhydrictis hoffstetteri, a large, otter-like member of the Mustelidae, of a genus that was previously unknown from Africa, and certainly testifies to North?South dispersal across the Mediterranean at some time during the early Pleistocene. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Biogeography; Carnivora; Felidae; Mammalia; Mediterranean area; Mustelidae; Pleistocene	biogeography; canid; carnivore; endemic species; felid; new genus; new species; paleoecology; Pleistocene; rare species; species occurrence; Algeria; Mediterranean Region; Canidae; Canis familiaris; Carnivora; Crocuta crocuta; Felidae; Felis silvestris; Homotherium; Hyaena hyaena; Hyaenidae; Lycaon; Lynx; Mammalia; Mellivora capensis; Mustelidae; Nyctereutes; Panthera; Panthera pardus; Vulpes							"Amani, F., La faune du gisement ? II, 316, pp. 847-852; Arambourg, C., Hoffstetter, R., Le gisement de Ternifine (1963) Archives de l'Institut de Pal?ontologie Humaine, 32, pp. 1-190; Argant, A., Carnivores quaternaires de Bourgogne (1991) Documents des Laboratoires de G?ologie de la Facult? des Sciences de Lyon, 115, pp. 1-301; Ball?sio, R., Monographie d'un Machairodus du gisement villafranchien de Sen?ze: Homotherium crenatidens Fabrini (1963) Travaux du Laboratoire de G?ologie de la Facult? des Sciences de Lyon, 9, pp. 1-129; Barycka, E., Middle and late Pleistocene Felidae and Hyaenidae of Poland (2008), Natura Optima dux Foundation Warszawa; Baryshnikov, G., Morphometrical variability of cheek teeth in cave bears. "Bona F., Sala B."	"Villafranchian-Galerian mammal faunas transition in South-Western Europe. The case of the late Early Pleistocene mammal fauna of the Frantoio locality, Arda River (Castell'Arquato, Piacenza, Northern Italy)"	2016	Geobios	49	5		329	347		fabgeo@libero.it	2	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.002	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994506040&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.002&partnerID=40&md5=624418d63888618c36151c691588e008	"Museo Geologico G. Cortesi (Castell'Arquato), Milano, Italy; Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra ?A. Desio?, Universit? degli Studi di Milano, Milano, Italy; Museo di Paleontologia e Preistoria ?Piero Leonardi?, Universit? degli Studi di Ferrara, Ferrara, Italy"	"Bona, F., Museo Geologico G. Cortesi (Castell'Arquato), Milano, Italy, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra ?A. Desio?, Universit? degli Studi di Milano, Milano, Italy; Sala, B., Museo di Paleontologia e Preistoria ?Piero Leonardi?, Universit? degli Studi di Ferrara, Ferrara, Italy"	"We investigated the fossil mammal assemblage from the late Early Pleistocene (early Galerian) site of the Arda River. Seven taxa were identified: one carnivore (Ursus dolinensis), five artiodactyls (Sus strozzii, Pseudodama farnetesis, Praemegaceros sp., Bison sp., and Hippopotamus sp.) and one perissodactyl (Stephanorhinus hundsheimensis). The Arda River faunal assemblage includes taxa already present in the Villafranchian, such as Pseudodama and Sus strozzii. The bear U.?dolinensis and the bison, a more evolved form than Bison (Eobison), are taxa typical of the beginning of the Galerian mammal age. Paleontological, sedimentological and paleobotanical data point towards the presence of woodlands settled on an alluvial plain with patches of grassland dated around 1.0?Ma. The continental sediments of the Arda River represent one of the first steps of the forming of the alluvial Po valley. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Early Galerian; Large mammals; Late Early Pleistocene; Northern Italy	fauna; fossil assemblage; fossil record; mammal; paleobotany; paleoenvironment; paleontology; sedimentology; transition zone; Villafranchian; Arda River; Castell'Arquato; Emilia-Romagna; Italy; Piacenza; Artiodactyla; Bison; Mammalia; Sus; Ursus					Fondazione Cassa di Risparmio di Piacenza e Vigevano	We are very indebted to C.?Francou (Museo Geologico ?G.?Cortesi?) for giving us the possibility to study these specimens and for his helpfulness and to the Fondazione di Piacenza e Vigevano for having financed the restoration of fossils. We thank the Parco Regionale dello Stirone e del Piacenziano. We thank Pierre-Olivier Antoine and an anonymous reviewer for critical reading of the manuscript and fruitful suggestions. We thank our colleague Claudio Berto for the production of the biochronological table. "Rinc?n A.D., Sol?rzano A., Macsotay O., McDonald H.G., N??ez-Flores M."	A new Miocene vertebrate assemblage from the R?o Yuca Formation (Venezuela) and the northernmost record of typical Miocene mammals of high latitude (Patagonian) affinities in South America	2016	Geobios	49	5		395	405		paleosur1974@gmail.com	1	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.005	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994388365&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.005&partnerID=40&md5=052864b0d2cee60edcce7ff8a5d3b45d	"Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cient?ficas (IVIC), Laboratorio de Paleontolog?a?Centro de Ecolog?a, Km 11 de la Carretera Panamericana, Edo. Miranda. Aptdo. 21.827, Caracas, Venezuela; Urbanizaci?n Trigal Norte, Avenida Atl?ntico, Valencia, Estado Carabobo, Venezuela; Bureau of Land Management, Utah State Office, 440 West 200 South, Salt Lake City, UT, United States"	"Rinc?n, A.D., Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cient?ficas (IVIC), Laboratorio de Paleontolog?a?Centro de Ecolog?a, Km 11 de la Carretera Panamericana, Edo. Aptdo. 21.827, Caracas, Venezuela; Sol?rzano, A., Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cient?ficas (IVIC), Laboratorio de Paleontolog?a?Centro de Ecolog?a, Km 11 de la Carretera Panamericana, Edo. Miranda. Aptdo. 21.827, Caracas, Venezuela; Macsotay, O., Urbanizaci?n Trigal Norte, Avenida Atl?ntico, Valencia, Estado Carabobo, Venezuela; McDonald, H.G., Bureau of Land Management, Utah State Office, 440 West 200 South, Salt Lake City, UT, United States; N??ez-Flores, M., Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cient?ficas (IVIC), Laboratorio de Paleontolog?a?Centro de Ecolog?a, Km 11 de la Carretera Panamericana, Edo. Miranda. Aptdo. 21.827, Caracas, Venezuela"	"Geological explorations of the basal beds of the R?o Yuca Formation (Tucupido region, Portuguesa State, western Venezuela) resulted in the recognition of a new vertebrate assemblage that includes eight taxa: the toxodont cf. Adinotherium, a Peltephilidae armadillo, the freshwaters fishes Platysilurus and Phractocephalus, the caiman Purussaurus, an indeterminate dolphin, turtles, and the previously recognized sloth Pseudoprepotherium venezuelanum. When compared with the higher latitudes faunas of Argentina and Chile, the presence of cf. Adinotherium and peltephilids in the Rio Yuca Formation is consistent, but not conclusive, with a Santacrucian to Frisian SALMA age. The associated fauna, as well recent apatite fission track analysis, indicates that the R?o Yuca assemblage is more likely younger in age, specifically Middle to Late Miocene. So far, the Miocene localities of the northern part of South America have provided a less prolific fossil record compared to the southern part of the continent (e.g., Santacrucian and Friasian faunas of Patagonia), but the present work documents the surprising occurrence of two taxa (Peltephilidae and Nesodontinae) common in southern high latitude faunas of South America, implying the persistence of the Santacrucian-Friasian genus Adinotherium in younger strata from northern South America, and that peltephilids were much more widespread during the Miocene than previously recognized. The presence of these common Patagonian taxa (Peltephilidae and Nesodontinae) in R?o Yuca also supports the hypothesis of prior researchers for the existence of biogeographical connections between the northern and southern portions of South America during the Late Oligocene or Early Miocene, which facilitated faunal interchange between the two regions. Finally, the biogeographical affinities of the freshwater fishes and the giant caiman (Purussaurus) indicate close relationships of the Tucupido region with the ancestral distribution of the Orinocoan?Amazonian drainage system. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Middle to Late Miocene; Nesodontinae; Peltephilidae; Pimelodidae; South America; Venezuela	fission track dating; fossil assemblage; mammal; Miocene; paleobiogeography; paleontology; taxonomy; Patagonia; Venezuela; Armadillo; Caiman; Mammalia; Manihot esculenta; Phractocephalus; Pimelodidae; Pisces; Platysilurus; sloths; Testudines; Vertebrata					"1096, IVIC, Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cient?ficas; IVIC, Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cient?ficas; PEII2012-456"	"The major funding support of this work was provided by Centro de Ecolog?a, Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cient?ficas (IVIC) grant 1096 to ADR, and also the Venezuelan Education University, Science, and Technology Ministry (MEUCT), research funding PEII2012-456 to ADR and AS. We thank Marisol Montellano-Ballesteros for the improvements of an early version of this manuscript. Finally, we thank Pierre-Olivier Antoine, John G. Lundberg and an anonymous reviewer for the considerable improvement they brought to the manuscript." Plicathyridine brachiopods (Athyridida) from the Frasnian (Late Devonian) of Western Europe and Middle East	2016	Geobios	49	5		381	393		bernard.mottequin@naturalsciences.be	2	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.004	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994406890&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.004&partnerID=40&md5=e36aa955baa649cda880d7c006803f7e	"Institut royal des Sciences naturelles de Belgique, D.O. Terre et Histoire de la Vie, rue Vautier 29, Bruxelles, Belgium; Universit? catholique de Lille, Groupe ISA, 48, boulevard Vauban, Lille cedex, France; Universit? de Li?ge, D?partement de G?ologie, all?e du 6-Ao?t, B?timent B18, Sart Tilman, Li?ge 1, Belgium"	"Mottequin, B., Institut royal des Sciences naturelles de Belgique, D.O. Terre et Histoire de la Vie, rue Vautier 29, Bruxelles, Belgium; Brice, D., Universit? catholique de Lille, Groupe ISA, 48, boulevard Vauban, Lille cedex, France; Marion, J.-M., Universit? de Li?ge, D?partement de G?ologie, all?e du 6-Ao?t, B?timent B18, Sart Tilman, Li?ge 1, Belgium; Simon, E., Institut royal des Sciences naturelles de Belgique, D.O. Terre et Histoire de la Vie, rue Vautier 29, Bruxelles, Belgium"	"Plicathyridine brachiopods (Athyridida) from the early?middle Frasnian of southern Belgium and northern France (Dinant Synclinorium) are systematically described for the first time. They include two species: Anathyris (Anathyris) calestiennensis nov. sp., and A. (A.) sp. indet. 1. They are uncommon in the mainly shally La Pr?e (Nismes Formation) and Ermitage (Moulin Li?naux Formation) members and are absent from the mixed argillaceous?carbonate late Frasnian succession in this area contrary to what is observed in Russia, notably in the East-European Platform and Siberia. In the Middle East, two species of Anathyris are recognized on the basis of a limited material from the Dascht-e-Nawar area in Afghanistan (A. (A.) sp. indet. 2) and the Kuh-e Kaftar mountains in Central Iran (A. (A.) sp. indet. 3). Anathyris (A.) calestiennensis nov. sp. is sometimes encrusted by epizoans (tabulate and rugose corals, and bryozoans) and rarely displays single, small circular drill holes. The past and current epizoan?brachiopod interactions are also discussed (Anathyris vs. Lingula, respectively). ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Athyridida; Brachiopods; Epizoans; Eurasia; Exhalant and inhalant currents; Frasnian	brachiopod; Frasnian; paleontology; parasite; Afghanistan; Belgium; France; Iran; Athyridida; Brachiopoda							"Adams, A., Descriptions of thirty four new species of bivalve Mollusca (Leda, Nucula, and Pythina) from the Cumingian collection (1856) Proceedings of the Zoological Society of London, 24, pp. 47-53; Ager, D.V., The epifauna of a Devonian spiriferid (1961) The Quarterly Journal of the Geological Society, London, 117, pp. 1-10; Alvarez, F., Devonian athyrid brachiopods from the Cantabrian Zone (NW Spain) (1990) Biostratigraphie du Pal?ozo?que, 11, pp. 1-311; Alvarez, F., Convergence in the evolution of Palaeozoic and Mesozoic brachiopods (2003) Journal of the Royal Society of New Zealand, 33, pp. 189-211; Alvarez, F., Athyridida (2007) Treatise on Invertebrate Paleontology: Part H, Brachiopoda, revised, 6 (Supplement), pp. 2742-2771. , P.A. Terre et Histoire de la Vie, rue Vautier 29, Belgium; email: bernard.mottequin@naturalsciences.be"			Elsevier Masson SAS					166995				English	Geobios	Article		Scopus	2-s2.0-84994406890
"Yamaguchi T., Goedert J.L., Kiel S."	"Marine ostracodes from Paleogene hydrocarbon seep deposits in Washington State, USA and their ecological structure"	2016	Geobios	49	5		407	422		tyamaguchi@kochi-u.ac.jp		10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.003	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994460866&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.003&partnerID=40&md5=81423fc1592542d2d19afa117c734563	"Center for Advanced Marine Core Research, Kochi University, B200 Monobe, Nankoku, Japan; Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, United States; Swedish Museum of Natural History, Department of Palaeobiology, Box 50007, Stockholm, Sweden"	"Yamaguchi, T., Center for Advanced Marine Core Research, Kochi University, B200 Monobe, Nankoku, Japan; Goedert, J.L., Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, United States; Kiel, S., Swedish Museum of Natural History, Department of Palaeobiology, Box 50007, Stockholm, Sweden"	"Invertebrate fossils described from ancient hydrocarbon seep deposits represent diverse groups, e.g., brachiopods, mollusks, decapod crustaceans, worm tubes, and rare echinoderms, but the fossil record of ostracodes from hydrocarbon seep deposits is still very limited, making their ecology and evolutionary history still little known. We found fossil ostracodes in eight Eocene to Oligocene hydrocarbon seep deposits in the Humptulips, Lincoln Creek, Makah, and Pysht formations in western Washington State, USA. They represent eleven taxa belonging to genera found in a wide range of shelf to slope habitats: Acanthocythereis, Loxoconcha?, Cytherella, Cytheropteron, Macropyxis?, Krithe, Paracosta, Pontocythere?, Propontocypris, Palmoconcha, and Neonesidea? Acanthocythereis acroreticulata from one late Oligocene seep deposit in the Lincoln Creek Formation is the oldest and northernmost record for this species. The hydrocarbon seep ostracode faunas from Washington appear to be benthos-dominated, showing the same ecological structure and pattern of phylogenetic relatedness as ostracodes from Miocene and Quaternary seep sediments from Italy and off Ireland. We suggest that the benthos-dominated structure has been stable for ostracodes in hydrocarbon seep environments and/or has a higher preservation potential than the nektobenthos-dominated structure. ? 2016"	Ecological structure; Eocene; Hydrocarbon seep; Oligocene; Ostracoda; Taxonomic distinctness; Washington State	Eocene; fossil record; hydrocarbon seep; Oligocene; ostracod; paleoecology; phylogenetics; taxonomy; United States; Washington [United States]; Brachiopoda; Crustacea; Cytherella; Cytheropteron; Echinodermata; Invertebrata; Krithe; Loxoconcha; Mollusca; Neonesidea; Ostracoda; Pontocythere; Propontocypris					"HU, Hiroshima University; UCSB, University of California, Santa Barbara; WSU, Washington State University; HKU, University of Hong Kong; UoL, University of London; UCSD, University of California, San Diego"	"This study was carried out at laboratories of Kanazawa and Nagoya Universities, Japan, and University of California, San Diego. Monaco P.	"Ichnocoenoses and taphocoenoses of posidoniid-bearing marl-limestone rhythmites and event beds, Toarcian-Aalenian, Northern Apennines, Italy"	2016	Geobios	49	5		365	379			1	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.006	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994527520&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.006&partnerID=40&md5=53b13e30b75b26a234725e731219857a	"Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Universit? degli Studi, via G. Pascoli snc, 06123, Perugia, Italy"	"Monaco, P., Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Universit? degli Studi, via G. Pascoli snc, 06123, Perugia, Italy"	"The Posidoniid-bearing rhythmic deposits, Toarcian to Aalenian (Early/Middle Jurassic) in age, of the Umbria-Marche basins (Fiuminata Colle Corno and Valdorbia type section) consist of hundred couplets, each composed by two semicouplets, a calcium carbonate-poor bed and a calcium carbonate-rich bed, respectively (CacO3 between 10% to 85%), where event tempestite beds randomly occurs. The aim of this work is to show ichnocoenoses and taphocoenoses as well as the faunistic variations of each semicouplet and event beds. Each couplet is ?30?cm thick in the Toarcian Rosso Ammonitico and up to 40?cm in the Aalenian Calcari e Marne a Posidonia Formation, where the sedimentation rate increased. Here, couplets were deposited in the dysaerobic/aerobic transition zone. The clay-rich portion contains abundant thin-shelled poikilaerobic bivalves and benthic foraminifers (whithout radiolarians) and shows oxygen-poor ichnocoenosis with Chondrites, while the taphocoenosis exhibits convex-upward disposition and disarticulated bivalve shells. Conversely, the limestone semicouplet is rich in radiolarians and thin-shelled bivalves, usually more burrowed (ichnocoenosis including Chondrites and few Planolites and Thalassinoides) than the former, with grouping, dispersion, biogenic fragmentation and orientation-reorientation. In all marl-limestone semicouplets, foraminifers and radiolarians exhibit a periodic inverse correlation in abundance, while thin-shelled bivalves are always abundant. Rhythmically disposed within the rhythmites are also event beds indicating an occasional oxygen-rich substrate, fine-grained calcarenitic tempestites with hummocky cross-stratification, and winnowed bed (thin shelled bivalve concentrations). These deposits are intensely bioturbated (ichnocoenosis including Skolithos, Planolites, Trypanites, Chondrites, and Thalassinoides). Taphocoenoses include fragmentation, grouping, surficial burrowing, biogenic reorientation, and deep burrowing. Ichnological and taphonomical features indicate high physical and biogenical reworking affecting sediments. The Jurassic depocenters of Valdorbia and Fiuminata that received rhythmical dilution (clay) or productivity (carbonate) cycles during Toarcian and Aalenian time can therefore strongly contribute to the study of ichnological and taphonomical variations in rhythmic conditions. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Clay-carbonate couplet; Early/Middle Jurassic; Ichnocoenosis; Italy; Posidoniid-bearing marl-limestone rhythmite; Taphocoenosis; Tempestite	Aalenian; fauna; fossil record; ichnology; limestone; marl; radiolaria; taphonomy; tempestite; Toarcian; Apennines; Italy; Bivalvia; Foraminifera; Planolites; Posidonia; Radiolaria (protozoans); Skolithos; Thalassinoides; Trypanites					95.00373	"Many thanks to E.?Garzanti and U.?Nicosia for critical improvements of this paper, and E.?Morettini, E.?Mattioli, M.?Nocchi, F.?Westall, M.?Claps and C.?Nini for faunal indications from the Fiuminata and Valdorbia sections. "Brzobohat? R., Kalvoda J., Fr?da J., Erban V."	Strontium isotope record of the Hygophum hygomii otoliths from the European middle Miocene	2016	Geobios	49	5		349	354		dino@sci.muni.cz	2	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.007	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994469276&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.007&partnerID=40&md5=605ed1dcc5a362f2d2515dd6460c82ef	"Department of Geology, Masaryk University, Brno, Kotl??sk? 2, Czech Republic; Czech Geological Survey, Kl?rov 3/131, Prague 1, Czech Republic; Department of Environmental Geosciences, Czech University of Life Sciences, Kam?ck? 129, Prague 6, Czech Republic; Czech Geological Survey, Geologick? 6, Praha 5, Czech Republic"	"Brzobohat?, R., Department of Geology, Masaryk University, Brno, Kotl??sk? 2, Czech Republic; Kalvoda, J., Department of Geology, Masaryk University, Brno, Kotl??sk? 2, Czech Republic; Fr?da, J., Czech Geological Survey, Kl?rov 3/131, Prague 1, Czech Republic, Department of Environmental Geosciences, Czech University of Life Sciences, Kam?ck? 129, Prague 6, Czech Republic; Erban, V., Czech Geological Survey, Geologick? 6, Praha 5, Czech Republic"	"87Sr/86Sr values from otoliths of the worldwide-distributed fish Hygophum hygomii are used for the purpose of isotope chemostratigraphy. In order to evaluate the potential of H.?hygomii otoliths for strontium (Sr) isotopic studies, we first compare the 87Sr/86Sr ratio of current representatives of the species with that of modern sea water. Then, three fossil otoliths of H.?hygomii collected in middle Miocene sediments of the Aquitaine Basin (Lafaurie locality, SW France) and the Carpathian Foredeep of the Central Paratethys (Brno-Kralovo Pole locality, SE Czech Republic) are analysed. The age inferred from the 87Sr/86Sr ratio at Lafaurie places the two analysed otoliths within the time interval of 15.5?15.1?Ma. This time interval matches the published early Langhian age obtained from the 87Sr/86Sr ratio of bivalves measured at the same locality. At the Brno-Kralovo Pole, the 87Sr/86Sr ratio of the analysed otolith returns a wider timespan of 14.78?13.10?Ma, falling into an interval of poor time resolution of the 87Sr/86Sr chemostratigraphy. Comparisons with published biostratigraphic and paleoclimatic data suggest that the analysed fossil otoliths of H.?hygomii were mineralized during the late part of the Langhian, at ?14.2?Ma. This work represents a first attempt to use otoliths for 87Sr/86Sr chemostratigraphy, and indicates that such a use may represent a powerful tool for testing stratigraphic correlations in the future. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Aquitaine Basin; Central Paratethys; Chemostratigraphy; Hygophum hygomii; Middle Miocene; Otolith; Sr isotopes	chemostratigraphy; fish; fossil record; isotopic ratio; Miocene; otolith; stratigraphic correlation; strontium isotope; Aquitaine Basin; France; Bivalvia; Hygophum hygomii							"Anthonissen, E., Ogg, J.G., Appendix 3. "Klein N., Schoch R.R., Schweigert G."	A juvenile eurysternid turtle (Testudines: Eurysternidae) from the upper Kimmeridgian (Upper Jurassic) of Nusplingen (SW Germany)	2016	Geobios	49	5		355	364		nicole.klein@smns-bw.de	1	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.008	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84994846437&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.008&partnerID=40&md5=79f9be643ec4e90e22dbcf757992e854	"Staatliches Museum f?r Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart, Germany"	"Klein, N., Staatliches Museum f?r Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart, Germany; Schoch, R.R., Staatliches Museum f?r Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart, Germany; Schweigert, G., Staatliches Museum f?r Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart, Germany"	"A juvenile turtle from the upper Kimmeridgian (Upper Jurassic) of Nusplingen is identified as an eurysternid turtle. It differs in plastral morphology from a juvenile eurysternid turtle from the latest Kimmerdigian of Kelheim described in the 19th century, which represents a comparably early developmental stage. Both juveniles have primordial ribs not yet transformed into costals and lack all other carapacial elements whereas the plastral elements are well developed. The new specimen from Nusplingen has a more robust plastron type when compared to the very gracile, bow- or arc-shaped plastron type of the formerly described juvenile. Both plastron types are also represented by yet undescribed additional juvenile, medium-sized and/or larger eurysternid specimens. The juvenile specimens thus likely document the presence of two morphologically very similar eurysternid taxa in the Upper Jurassic of southern Germany. Both plastron types are different from those described for Idiochelys and Solnhofia but may resemble plastron morphology of Eurysternum, which is, however, only incompletely known. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Eurysternidae; Ontogeny; Plastral morphology; Turtle diversity	fossil record; juvenile; Kimmeridgian; morphology; ontogeny; paleontology; turtle; Baden-Wurttemberg; Germany; Nusplingen; Eurysternidae; Eurysternum; Idiochelys; Solnhofia; Testudines					"UM, Universit? de Montpellier"	"Markus Rieter (SMNS) is acknowledged for the skilful preparation of the Nusplingen specimen. "Takeda Y., Inoue S., Hasebe Y."	"Irregular calcareous sheets preserved in a conch of the Cretaceous ammonoid Hypophylloceras from Hokkaido, Japan"	2016	Geobios	49	4		319	327		ytakeda@um.u-tokyo.ac.jp		10.1016/j.geobios.2016.05.003	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84991584879&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.05.003&partnerID=40&md5=d7ef728e6e0b78d72f1d31c940013fae	"Department of Earth and Planetary Science, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Graduate School of Frontier Biosciences, Osaka University, 1-3 Yamadaoka, Suita, Osaka, Japan; Hokkaido University Shuma-no-kai, #354 Clubs and Societies Building, Kita 17, Nishi 12, Kita-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan"	"Takeda, Y., Department of Earth and Planetary Science, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Inoue, S., Graduate School of Frontier Biosciences, Osaka University, 1-3 Yamadaoka, Suita, Osaka, Japan, Hokkaido University Shuma-no-kai, #354 Clubs and Societies Building, Kita 17, Nishi 12, Kita-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan; Hasebe, Y., Hokkaido University Shuma-no-kai, #354 Clubs and Societies Building, Kita 17, Nishi 12, Kita-ku, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan"	"The mantle tissue is essential for understanding the diverse ecology and shell morphology of ammonoid cephalopods. Here, we report on irregular calcareous sheets in a well-preserved shell of a Late Cretaceous phylloceratid ammonoid Hypophylloceras subramosum from Hokkaido, Japan, and their significance for repairing the conch through the mantle inside the body chamber. The sheets are composed of nacreous layers arranged parallel to the irregularly distorted outer whorl surface. The nacreous sheets formed earlier are unevenly distributed and attached to the outer shell wall locally, whereas the last formed sheet covers a wide area of the outer shell wall. The absence of any interruption of ribbing around the irregular area suggests that these sheets were secreted inside the body chamber from the inner mantle. Gross morphological and X-ray computed tomography observations revealed that the spacing of septal formation was not affected by this event. The complex structure of the irregular sheets suggests a highly flexible mantle inside the body chamber. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Ammonoid; Cretaceous; Irregular shell secretion; Japan; Shell microstructure; X-ray CT scan	ammonite; Cretaceous; microstructure; morphology; secretion; shell; Hokkaido; Japan; Ammonoidea; Cephalopoda; Phylloceratida					"Chief, University of Tokyo; 16J06269, JSPS, Japan Society for the Promotion of Science; NHM, Natural History Museum"	"We thank Kazushige Tanabe, Takenori Sasaki (both at UMUT), Daisuke Aiba (Mikasa City Museum), Amane Tajika (Zurich University), and Ren? "Raisossadat S.N., Noori H."	"Lower Cretaceous gastropods from the Qayen area, Eastern Iran"	2016	Geobios	49	4		293	301		snraeisosadat@birjand.ac.ir		10.1016/j.geobios.2016.06.001	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84991729012&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.06.001&partnerID=40&md5=3ab02d2903ce2ce93b34305fcded5fca	"Geology Department, Faculty of Science, University of Birjand, Birjand, Iran"	"Raisossadat, S.N., Geology Department, Faculty of Science, University of Birjand, Birjand, Iran; Noori, H., Geology Department, Faculty of Science, University of Birjand, Birjand, Iran"	"Four gastropod genera are newly recorded from Lower Cretaceous deposits of the Qayen area, Eastern Iran. Based on the paleoecological interpretation of the faunal assemblage and especially on the newly identified gastropods, a shallow temperate marine environment is suggested for the fossil-bearing carbonate rocks. The gastropod assemblage shows a typically Tethyan composition comparable to those already reported from the Caucasus and Eastern Europe. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Aptian; Gastropoda; Iran; Paleobiogeography; Paleoecology; Sistan suture zone; South Khorasan Province	Aptian; carbonate rock; fossil assemblage; gastropod; marine environment; new record; paleobiogeography; paleoecology; suture zone; temperate environment; Iran; Sistan; South Khorasan; Gastropoda					"NHM, Natural History Museum; University of Birjand"	"We thank Dr. Heinz Kollmann (Natural History Museum, Vienna) for his valuable comments during this research and help for the finalization of this paper. "Boyd C., McIlroy D."	Three-dimensional morphology and palaeobiology of the trace fossil Dactyloidites jordii nov. isp. from the Carboniferous of England	2016	Geobios	49	4		257	264		c.boyd@mun.ca	2	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.05.004	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84991573052&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.05.004&partnerID=40&md5=e9a76377a005e0e8acb9bcc3b3d9917b	"Memorial University of Newfoundland, Department of Earth Sciences, 300 Prince Philip Drive, St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada"	"Boyd, C., Memorial University of Newfoundland, Department of Earth Sciences, 300 Prince Philip Drive, St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada; McIlroy, D., Memorial University of Newfoundland, Department of Earth Sciences, 300 Prince Philip Drive, St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada"	"The diverse ichnological assemblage from the outcrops near Howick (Northumberland, United Kingdom) is exceptionally well-preserved. Among these Carboniferous ichnotaxa is a new ichnospecies of Dactyloidites. Specimens were collected and processed using high-resolution serial grinding and photography to produce an accurate and precise three-dimensional model of these new burrows in full colour. The model produced in association with petrographic thin sections and field observations is used as the basis for comparison between Dactyloidites jordii nov. isp. and other ichnospecies of Dactyloidites. The current taxonomic status of the ichnogenus is examined and reviewed. D. jordii nov. isp. is a broadly bisymmetrical, stellate to palmate burrow composed of numerous long, narrow rays that exhibit three orders of branching arranged into tiered galleries radiating from a central shaft. The trace maker is suggested to be a vermiform organism with an adaptive burrowing strategy that facilitates alteration of its burrow construction to accommodate suboptimal sediment conditions. The adaptive nature of trace-making organisms and the inherent anisotropy of many burrowed media highlight the need for ichnologists to provide a type series rather than a single holotype, in order to capture the inherent range of common burrow morphologies. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Dactyloidites; Ichnology; Ichnotaxonomy; Serial grinding; Stainmore Formation; Three-dimensional reconstruction	burrow; Carboniferous; ichnofacies; ichnology; morphology; paleobiology; taxonomy; three-dimensional modeling; trace fossil; England; United Kingdom					"NSERC, Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada; Canada Research Chairs"	"This work was supported by an NSERC Discovery Grant, and a Canada Research Chair awarded to D.?McIlroy. M.?Garton is thanked for his field assistance with sample collection. J.?Howell is thanked for introducing us to the Howick sections. N.?Djan-Ch?kar is thanked for her assistance with type material. The late Jordi M.?de Gibert is thanked for early insightful discussion at Ichnia 2012. It is to him that this work is dedicated. Alfred Uchman and Andrew Rindsberg thanked for their helpful and insightful reviews. "Baeza-Carratal? J.F., Garc?a Joral F., Tent-Mancl?s J.E."	Brachiopod faunal exchange through an epioceanic-epicontinental transitional area from the Early Jurassic South Iberian platform system	2016	Geobios	49	4		243	255		jf.baeza@ua.es	2	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.05.005	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84991688482&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.05.005&partnerID=40&md5=9ca44703c4b03b46dd68f3f9441e7f6c	"Departamento de Ciencias de la Tierra y Medio Ambiente, Universidad Alicante, Apdo. 99, San Vicente del Raspeig, Alicante, Spain; Departamento de Paleontolog?a, Facultad de Ciencias Geol?gicas. Universidad Complutense, C/Jos? Antonio Novais, 12, Madrid, Spain"	"Baeza-Carratal?, J.F., Departamento de Ciencias de la Tierra y Medio Ambiente, Universidad Alicante, Apdo. 99, San Vicente del Raspeig, Alicante, Spain; Garc?a Joral, F., Departamento de Paleontolog?a, Facultad de Ciencias Geol?gicas. Universidad Complutense, C/Jos? Antonio Novais, 12, Madrid, Spain; Tent-Mancl?s, J.E., Departamento de Ciencias de la Tierra y Medio Ambiente, Universidad Alicante, Apdo. 99, San Vicente del Raspeig, Alicante, Spain"	"The La Mola region (eastern External Betic Zone) can be regarded as one of the easternmost complete Jurassic successions of the Betic Cordillera in the Iberian Peninsula, but the paleogeographical setting of their outcrops remains widely discussed. Analysis of brachiopod assemblages from the Lower Jurassic improves the accuracy of previous paleogeographical data, enabling identification of a mainly epioceanic transitional area in which influences of epicontinental habitats are also detected. Assemblage 1, mainly with a Mediterranean affinity but also sharing several constituents with the African and Northeastern Iberian basins, typifies the Sinemurian?Pliensbachian transition. Assemblage 2, as a whole, shows a transitional character between epioceanic and epicontinental habitats; it is subdivided into two successive and interrelated sub-assemblages: Ass. 2a (Demonense?Tenuicostatum Zones) reveals a free connection with the epioceanic Subbetic area, whereas Ass. 2b (Uppermost Pliensbachian?Lower Toarcian) shows a closer relationship with epicontinental environments. Assemblage 3 (Uppermost Spinatum?basal Serpentinum Zones) is commonly recorded in the peri-Iberian epicontinental platform system integrated within the NW-European bioprovince, but it can also be regarded as a marginal assemblage that is widespread in the westernmost Tethyan margin prior to the Early Toarcian extinction event. Assemblage 2 constitutes a suitable index for assessing the paleobiogeographical affinity of the La Mola region, as Ass. 2a is progressively replaced by Ass. 2b, thus triggering the arrival of epicontinental taxa to the more intra-epioceanic Subbetic environments, inferring a possible connection through the La Mola transitional slope. Consequently, this region enabled a faunal mixing and exchange between both environments, and La Mola likely remained as an area that would facilitate migration and an effective dispersal seaway or, at least, did not constitute an ecological filter-barrier for brachiopods. Biostratigraphical data from brachiopods and ammonites are correlated for the first time in La Mola, refining and calibrating biochronostratigraphical gaps in the pre-Domerian deposits where biochronological markers are usually scarce, and around the Pliensbachian?Toarcian boundary, a crucial timespan in which the Early Toarcian extinction event took place. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Betic Cordillera; Biostratigraphy; Brachiopod assemblage; Early Jurassic; Geographic distribution; Paleobiogeography	ammonite; biochronology; biostratigraphy; brachiopod; fossil assemblage; geographical distribution; Jurassic; paleobiogeography; Betic Cordillera; Iberian Peninsula; Spain; Brachiopoda							"Ager, D.V., Some Mesozoic Brachiopods in the Tethys region (1967) Aspects of Tethyan Biogeography, 7, pp. 135-151. , C.G. "Systematical position and paleoecology of the endemic deer Megaceroides algericus Lydekker, 1890 (Cervidae, Mammalia) from the late Pleistocene-early Holocene of North Africa"	2016	Geobios	49	4		265	283		romancroitor@europe.com		10.1016/j.geobios.2016.05.002	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84991579892&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.05.002&partnerID=40&md5=bcfee27809dab9aef18d5d033b32653e	"Aix-Marseille University, CNRS, UMR 7269, MMSH BP674, 5, rue du Ch?teau-de-l'Horloge, Aix-en-Provence, France; Institute of Zoology, Academy of Sciences of Moldova, Academiei str. 1, Chi?in?u, Moldova"	"Croitor, R., Aix-Marseille University, CNRS, UMR 7269, MMSH BP674, 5, rue du Ch?teau-de-l'Horloge, Aix-en-Provence, France, Institute of Zoology, Academy of Sciences of Moldova, Academiei str. 1, Chi?in?u, Moldova"	"The unusual cranial morphology of the endemic extinct African deer Megaceroides algericus (Lydekker, 1890) is described. Some details of cranial and dental morphology suggest that M. algericus is closely related to the Eurasian giant deer Megaloceros giganteus (Blumenbach, 1799). The paper presents also a discussion on paleoecology and functional morphology of M. algericus, as well as its origin, phylogenetic and taxonomic position. Megaloceros mugarensis (Di Stefano, 1996) from the middle Pleistocene of Levant is regarded as a probable forerunner of M. algericus. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Cervidae; Cranial morphology; Ecomorphology; Evolution; Pachyostosis; Paleobiogeography; Taxonomy	cranium; deer; ecomorphology; endemic species; evolution; extinction; functional morphology; Holocene; paleobiogeography; paleoecology; Pleistocene; taxonomy; Levant; Mediterranean Region; North Africa; Cervidae; Mammalia; Megaloceros; Megaloceros giganteus					"NHM, Natural History Museum; NMNH, National Museum of Natural History; AMU, Aix-Marseille Universit?" "Somerville I.D., Rodr?guez S., Said I."	Carboniferous aulate corals from Azrou-Khenifra Basin (Morocco): Distribution and phylogenetic relationships	2016	Geobios	49	4		303	317		ian.somerville@ucd.ie		10.1016/j.geobios.2016.05.001	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84991738184&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.05.001&partnerID=40&md5=c11126248f0c463cd81f5962733b0aee	"UCD School of Earth Sciences, University College Dublin, Belfield, Dublin, 4, Ireland; Dpto. de Paleontolog?a, Universidad Complutense de Madrid, c/Jos? Antonio Novais, 12, Madrid, Spain; Instituto de Geociencias, CSIC, UCM, c/Jos? Antonio Novais 12, Madrid, Spain; Division du Patrimoine G?ologique, Direction du D?veloppement Minier, Minist?re de l??nergie, des Mines, de l'Eau et de l'Environnement, rue Abou Marouane Essadi BP, Rabat Instituts, Haut Agdal, Rabat, Morocco"	"Somerville, I.D., UCD School of Earth Sciences, University College Dublin, Belfield, Dublin, 4, Ireland; Rodr?guez, S., Dpto. de Paleontolog?a, Universidad Complutense de Madrid, c/Jos? Antonio Novais, 12, Madrid, Spain, Instituto de Geociencias, CSIC, UCM, c/Jos? Antonio Novais 12, Madrid, Spain; Said, I., Division du Patrimoine G?ologique, Direction du D?veloppement Minier, Minist?re de l??nergie, des Mines, de l'Eau et de l'Environnement, rue Abou Marouane Essadi BP, Rabat Instituts, Haut Agdal, Rabat, Morocco"	"The Carboniferous outcrops from the Azrou-Khenifra Basin (central Morocco) have yielded solitary and fasciculate aulate corals. Although mostly rare, their presence has significance for extending the known stratigraphic range of two genera. Both Solenodendron and Semenoffia which were previously restricted to the Tournaisian-Vis?an interval are now recognised to range up into the Serpukhovian. Moreover, Solenodendron is now last recorded in lower Bashkirian strata, having survived the end-Serpukhovian (mid-Carboniferous) faunal crisis. New phylogenetic relationships are proposed within this aulate group of corals for the western Palaeotethys, based on detailed examination of their morphology, microstructure and stratigraphic range. The distribution of solitary and fasciculate aulate corals in the Azrou-Khenifra Basin (Morocco) is comparable with that of the B?char Basin (Algeria), and some species are commonly recorded in Europe. A new species, Aulokoninckophyllum potyi is described. ? 2016"	Aulate rugose corals; Biostratigraphy; Mississippian; Morocco; Phylogeny; Systematics; Western Palaeotethys	biostratigraphy; coral; Mississippian; new species; outcrop; phylogenetics; phylogeny; taxonomy; Azrou-Khenifra Basin; Meknes-Tafilalet; Morocco; Anthozoa					"MRIS, Ministry of Research, Innovation and Science"	"The present research has been carried out with the funds provided by the Research project CGL2012-30922BTE of the Spanish Ministry of Research and Innovation. This article is a contribution to the IGCP 596. The authors thank the cooperation of the Department of Mines and Development of the Minist?re de l?Energie et des Mines of Morocco. The thin sections used for this study have been prepared by Isabel D?az Mej?as. We are grateful to Wei Lin for providing useful data on Carboniferous aulate corals from China. The careful reviews of the manuscript by O.?Kossovaya, E.?Poty and M.?Aretz allowed a notable improvement in the final version." "Ingicco T., van den Bergh G., de Vos J., Castro A., Amano N., Bautista A."	"A new species of Celebochoerus (Suidae, Mammalia) from the Philippines and the paleobiogeography of the genus Celebochoerus Hooijer, 1948"	2016	Geobios	49	4		285	291		ingicco@mnhn.fr		10.1016/j.geobios.2016.05.006	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84991607849&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.05.006&partnerID=40&md5=9e268b472e410932763dfc7d073979fe	"D?partement de Pr?histoire, UMR 7194, Mus?um national d'Histoire naturelle, Mus?e de l'Homme, 17, place du Trocad?ro, Paris, France; Centre for Archaeological Science, School of Earth & Environmental Sciences, University of Wollongong, Wollongong, NSW, Australia; Naturalis Biodiversity Center, P.O. Box 9517, RA Leiden, Netherlands; Geology Division, National Museum of the Philippines, Taft Ave, Ermita, Manila, Metro Manila, Philippines; Cultural Properties Division, National Museum of the Philippines, Taft Ave, Ermita, Manila, Metro Manila, Philippines"	"Ingicco, T., D?partement de Pr?histoire, UMR 7194, Mus?um national d'Histoire naturelle, Mus?e de l'Homme, 17, place du Trocad?ro, Paris, France; van den Bergh, G., Centre for Archaeological Science, School of Earth & Environmental Sciences, University of Wollongong, Wollongong, NSW, Australia; de Vos, J., Naturalis Biodiversity Center, P.O. Box 9517, RA Leiden, Netherlands; Castro, A., Geology Division, National Museum of the Philippines, Taft Ave, Ermita, Manila, Metro Manila, Philippines; Amano, N., D?partement de Pr?histoire, UMR 7194, Mus?um national d'Histoire naturelle, Mus?e de l'Homme, 17, place du Trocad?ro, Paris, France; Bautista, A., Cultural Properties Division, National Museum of the Philippines, Taft Ave, Ermita, Manila, Metro Manila, Philippines"	"Celebochoerus is a unique suid having extremely large upper tusks, and which was to date only known from the Pliocene-Pleistocene of Sulawesi Island in Indonesia. Here, we report on the discovery of a canine fragment referable to Celebochoerus from the Cagayan Valley of Luzon, Northern Philippines. We name a new species, Celebochoerus cagayanensis nov. sp., which differs from the Sulawesi species Celebochoerus heekereni in having mesial and distal enamel bands on the upper canines. We see these characteristics as symplesiomorphic in suids and propose a migration route from the Philippines to Sulawesi, possibly out of Taiwan, which would have occurred independently from the better known Pleistocene migration route from India into Java. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS"	Cagayan Valley; Canine; Celebochoerus cagayanensis nov. sp; Migration route; Southeastern Asia; Suidae; Sulawesi	enamel; mammal; migration route; new species; paleobiogeography; Pliocene-Pleistocene boundary; Cagayan Valley; Greater Sunda Islands; Luzon; Philippines; Sulawesi; Sunda Isles; Mammalia; Suidae					"OVPRED, Office of the Vice President for Research and Economic Development, University of Iowa; UP, University of the Philippines; FT100100384, ARC, Australian Research Council; Creative Work and Research Committee, Valparaiso University"	"The permit to survey was granted by the National Museum of the Philippines directors Jeremy Barns and Anna Labrador. Financial support was provided through Creative Work and Research Grant of the Office of Vice President for Academic Affairs of the University of the Philippines Diliman (TI), Global Exploration grant of National Geographic (TI with Alfred Pawlik), the Quaternary and Prehistory Erasmus Mundus program (JdV), and an Australian Research Council grant (GvdB: FT100100384 ). We specially thank Robert de Ocampo for allowing us the access of specimens of Celebochoerus stored in the Geology Division of the National Museum of the Philippines. We also thank Susan Hayes for assistance with editing. We acknowledge Geobios editors (Gilles Escarguel and Pierre-Olivier Antoine) and reviewers (Jan van der Made and Pierre-Henri Fabre) for improving this manuscript." "?ukowiak M., Dumitriu S.D., Ionesi V."	First fossil record of early Sarmatian didemnid ascidian spicules (Tunicata) from Moldova	2016	Geobios	49	3		201	209		mlukowiak@twarda.pan.pl	2	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.01.020	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84971624000&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.01.020&partnerID=40&md5=66ca0af428c4322f014979187ed1fe47	"Institute of Paleobiology, Polish Academy of Sciences, Twarda 51/55, Warszawa, Poland; Department of Geology, Alexandru Ioan Cuza University of Ia?i, Carol I Blv. 20A, Ia?i, Romania"	"?ukowiak, M., Institute of Paleobiology, Polish Academy of Sciences, Twarda 51/55, Warszawa, Poland; Dumitriu, S.D., Department of Geology, Alexandru Ioan Cuza University of Ia?i, Carol I Blv. 20A, Ia?i, Romania; Ionesi, V., Department of Geology, Alexandru Ioan Cuza University of Ia?i, Carol I Blv. 20A, Ia?i, Romania"	"Numerous ascidian spicules are reported for the first time from the lower Sarmatian Darabani-Mitoc Clays of Coste?ti, north-western Moldova. The biological interpretation of the studied sclerites allows distinguishing at least three morphospecies (Polysyncraton-like, Trididemnum-like, and Didemnum-like) within the Didemnidae family. Eight other morphological types of spicules are classified as indeterminate didemnids. Most of the studied spicules are morphologically similar to those of Recent shallow-water taxa from the Mediterranean Sea. In contrast, some sclerites resemble those of taxa from the Indo-Pacific region. The greater size of the studied spicules, compared to that of present-day didemnids, suggests favorable physicochemical conditions within the Sarmatian Sea. The presence of these stenohaline tunicates that prefer normal salinity seems to confirm latest hypotheses regarding mixo-mesohaline conditions during the early Sarmatian. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS." "?ukowiak, M.; Institute of Paleobiology, Polish Academy of Sciences, Twarda 51/55, Poland; email: mlukowiak@twarda.pan.pl"			Elsevier Masson SAS					166995				English	Geobios	Article		Scopus	2-s2.0-84971624000
"Uchman A., Johnson M.E., Rebelo A.C., Melo C., Cordeiro R., Ramalho R.S., ?vila S.P."	Vertically-oriented trace fossil Macaronichnus segregatis from Neogene of Santa Maria Island (Azores; NE Atlantic) records vertical fluctuations of the coastal groundwater mixing zone on a small oceanic island	2016	Geobios	49	3		229	241		alfred.uchman@uj.edu.pl	4	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.01.016	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84974688474&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.01.016&partnerID=40&md5=d3a0b5d0719f7de6895fc88696aa7dcf	"Institute of Geological Sciences, Jagiellonian University, Oleandry 2a, Krak?w, Poland; Department of Geosciences, Williams College, Williamstown, MA, United States; CIBIO-A?ores, Centro de Investiga??o em Biodiversidade e Recursos Gen?ticos, InBIO Laborat?rio Associado, P?lo dos A?ores, A?ores, Portugal; Departamento de Biologia, Universidade dos A?ores, Ponta Delgada, A?ores, Portugal; MPB-Marine PalaeoBiogeography Working Group, University of the Azores, Rua da M?e de Deus, Portugal; SMNS - Staatliches Museum f?r Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart, Germany; Departamento de Geoci?ncias, Universidade dos A?ores, Ponta Delgada, Portugal; School of Earth Sciences, University of Bristol, Wills Memorial Building, Queen's Road, Bristol, United Kingdom"	"Uchman, A., Institute of Geological Sciences, Jagiellonian University, Oleandry 2a, Krak?w, Poland; Johnson, M.E., Department of Geosciences, Williams College, Williamstown, MA, United States; Rebelo, A.C., CIBIO-A?ores, Centro de Investiga??o em Biodiversidade e Recursos Gen?ticos, InBIO Laborat?rio Associado, P?lo dos A?ores, A?ores, Portugal, Departamento de Biologia, Universidade dos A?ores, Ponta Delgada, A?ores, Portugal, MPB-Marine PalaeoBiogeography Working Group, University of the Azores, Rua da M?e de Deus, Portugal, SMNS - Staatliches Museum f?r Naturkunde Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart, Germany; Melo, C., MPB-Marine PalaeoBiogeography Working Group, University of the Azores, Rua da M?e de Deus, Portugal, Departamento de Geoci?ncias, Universidade dos A?ores, Ponta Delgada, Portugal; Cordeiro, R., CIBIO-A?ores, Centro de Investiga??o em Biodiversidade e Recursos Gen?ticos, InBIO Laborat?rio Associado, P?lo dos A?ores, A?ores, Portugal, Departamento de Biologia, Universidade dos A?ores, Ponta Delgada, A?ores, Portugal, MPB-Marine PalaeoBiogeography Working Group, University of the Azores, Rua da M?e de Deus, Portugal; Ramalho, R.S., School of Earth Sciences, University of Bristol, Wills Memorial Building, Queen's Road, Bristol, United Kingdom; ?vila, S.P., CIBIO-A?ores, Centro de Investiga??o em Biodiversidade e Recursos Gen?ticos, InBIO Laborat?rio Associado, P?lo dos A?ores, A?ores, Portugal, Departamento de Biologia, Universidade dos A?ores, Ponta Delgada, A?ores, Portugal, MPB-Marine PalaeoBiogeography Working Group, University of the Azores, Rua da M?e de Deus, Portugal"	"The trace fossil Macaronichnus segregatis is interpreted to be produced by opheliid polychaetes that feed on epigranular microbes and organic matter commonly abundant in shallow-marine foreshore sands. Resulting traces are horizontal and typically random in orientation, but sometimes perpendicular to the shoreline. However, M. segregatis in Neogene sandy sediments from Santa Maria Island in the Azores shows a vertical or sub-vertical orientation. This is explained by vertical flow of pore waters and oxygenation fluctuations within the mixing zone between interstitial marine and freshwater aquifers-where epigranular microbes and organic matter are most enriched. On reefless volcanic oceanic islands like the Azores, insular shelves are invariably steep, narrow, and exposed to strong swell. Aquifers in this setting respond rapidly to small changes on account of limited shelf space and a high potential differential that stimulates a vertical shift in habitats. Freshwater aquifers on small, low-relief oceanic islands form a thin lens, the edges of which are wedged against marine interstitial waters and migrate up and down in response to changes caused by tides, storm surges and precipitation. During the Late Miocene-Early Pliocene, Santa Maria was an island fitting this description. Due to a waning volcanism, intense marine erosion and gradual submersion, the island developed a wide shallow platform covered by sandy shoals, as exemplified by the Malbusca section with vertical Macaronichnus. The process, however, is more acute on small, reflective beaches perched on rocky island coasts. Here, sand blankets cover small ramps cut in the basaltic bedrock, resulting in very limited freshwater aquifers subject to strong changes due to the low permeability of basalts. The mixing zone is therefore forced to migrate chiefly up and down, mostly due to tides. The same response is dramatic in sandy fillings trapped in basalt fissures. As a consequence, the producer of Macaronichnus was tightly constrained in movement. Both situations occur in the ""Pedra-que-pica"" section on Santa Maria. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS." "Brachaniec T., Salamon M.A., Szopa K., Gedl P., Brom K.R., Le?ko K."	Origin of Jurassic-Cretaceous neptunian dikes from the Cracow-Czestochowa Upland in southern Poland	2016	Geobios	49	3		155	165		paleo.crinoids@poczta.fm	1	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.01.021	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84973523384&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.01.021&partnerID=40&md5=49bae2fc896ac1348c7ef3843e779582	"University of Silesia, Faculty of Earth Sciences, Bedzi?ska Str. 60, Sosnowiec, Poland; Institute of Geological Sciences, Polish Academy of Sciences, Senacka Str. 1, Cracow, Poland"	"Brachaniec, T., University of Silesia, Faculty of Earth Sciences, Bedzi?ska Str. 60, Sosnowiec, Poland; Salamon, M.A., University of Silesia, Faculty of Earth Sciences, Bedzi?ska Str. 60, Sosnowiec, Poland; Szopa, K., University of Silesia, Faculty of Earth Sciences, Bedzi?ska Str. 60, Sosnowiec, Poland; Gedl, P., Institute of Geological Sciences, Polish Academy of Sciences, Senacka Str. 1, Cracow, Poland; Brom, K.R., University of Silesia, Faculty of Earth Sciences, Bedzi?ska Str. 60, Sosnowiec, Poland; Le?ko, K., University of Silesia, Faculty of Earth Sciences, Bedzi?ska Str. 60, Sosnowiec, Poland"	"Neptunian dikes, representing deposit-filling fractures in older rocks, have long attracted the attention of paleontologists because they may provide unique insights into ancient cryptic submarine cave ecosystems. In the epicratonic Poland, fossil-bearing neptunian dikes are especially well known in Upper Jurassic (mainly Oxfordian) strata. However, the age, origin and faunal composition of these dikes remain the subject of debates. To address these issues, we integrated new paleontological and petrographic data from the Janina Quarry in southern Poland, where neptunian dikes are particularly well exposed. On the basis of sedimentary facies and faunal content occurring as infill of the analyzed dikes, we recognized three distinct stages of Neptunian dike development. Initially, these dikes represented fissures in the sea bottom resulting from the intense Oxfordian and/or Kimmeridgian synsedimentary processes related to Meso- and Neocimmerian tectonic movements. These initial voids were colonized by small crinoids (cyrtocrinids) and brachiopods (lacunosselids), which resulted in the formation of bioclastic limestones. This is the first Mesozoic record of cryptic cyrtocrinids, which implies that migration of this echinoderm group to cryptic habitats has already occurred in the Late Jurassic, consistent with the so-called Mesozoic Marine Revolution. After the initial opening and subsequent rapid sedimentary filling of voids, rejuvenation of these dikes occurred in the Aptian-Cenomanian that was likely induced by the Austrian tectonic phase. Reopened fissures were subsequently filled by rare allochthonous echinoderms and sandstones containing unusually high (5% vol.) content of heavy minerals implying the Bohemian Massif as the most probable source area. The neptunian dikes were finally reopened during the Turonian-Santonian that was probably related to the subhercynnian tectonic phase. They were presumably inhabited by annelids and ultimately filled by a micritic sediment subsequently bioturbated by infaunal echinoids. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS."	Cretaceous; Echinoderms; Janina Quarry; Jurassic; Neptunian dike; Poland; Submarine cave ecosystem	Cretaceous; dike; echinoderm; Jurassic; paleontology; quarry; submarine cave; Cracow; Czestochowa [Slaskie]; Malopolskie; Poland [Central Europe]; Slaskie; Annelida; Brachiopoda; Echinodermata; Echinoida; Neptunia; Pelmatozoa					"KNOW, Krajowy Naukowy Osrodek Wiodacy; AGH, Akademia G?rniczo-Hutnicza im. Stanislawa Staszica; KNOW, Krajowy Naukowy Osrodek Wiodacy"	"Krzysztof Brom, Katarzyna Le?ko and Krzysztof Szopa thank the Leading National Research Centre (KNOW) for financial support from funds received by the Centre for Polar Studies for the period 2014?2018. Thanks are also due to three other reviewers, including an anonymous one, Dr. Alenka Eva ?rne, and Dr. Sylvain Charbonnier, as well as to Geobios Editor Dr. Gilles Escarguel, for their constructive remarks and comments that helped us to improve the present paper." "Filipiak P., Zato? M."	"Non-calcified macroalgae from the lower Famennian (Upper Devonian) of the Holy Cross Mountains, Poland"	2016	Geobios	49	3		191	200		filipiak@us.edu.pl	3	10.1016/j.geobios.2016.01.019	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84973879660&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.01.019&partnerID=40&md5=e5fcaf1abce6c628ff3a207adbf63ac2	"Faculty of Earth Sciences, University of Silesia, Be dzi?ska 60, Sosnowiec, Poland"	"Filipiak, P., Faculty of Earth Sciences, University of Silesia, Be dzi?ska 60, Sosnowiec, Poland; Zato?, M., Faculty of Earth Sciences, University of Silesia, Be dzi?ska 60, Sosnowiec, Poland"	"Non-calcified algal remains were collected from the lower Famennian deposits at the Kowala quarry in the Holy Cross Mountains, central Poland. Each specimen is represented solely by vegetative organs. On the basis of the material collected, a new algal genus and species has been formally erected. Vittella dixii nov. gen., nov. sp. (Order ?Bryopsidales) includes thalli consisting of long bundles of hair-like filament structures arranged in parallel fashion to the thallus length. Some other algal remains are regarded as Inocaulis-like forms. They possess long, flat blades with entire margins, and are ornamented with very dense, hair-like projections. The rest of the specimens found so far has been illustrated and tentatively classified as probably belonging to either Bryopsidales or Dasycladales algae. The exceptional preservation of the non-calcified algal thalli investigated suggests that special taphonomic conditions have prevailed during sedimentation of the lower part of the Famennian Kowala section. These may have involved rather rapid burial in oxygen-restricted (dysoxic and anoxic) sea-bottom environment, inhibiting the activities of scavengers and bioturbators, as well as oxidative degradation. The preservation of the algae, together with sedimentological and geochemical characteristics of the host rocks indicate that they rather represent parautochthonous assemblage, buried close to their natural habitat. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS."	Bryopsidales; Dasycladales; Famennian; Holy Cross Mountains; Non-calcified algae; Taphonomic window	bioturbation; Famennian; green alga; macroalga; new genus; new species; preservation; scavenging (feeding); taphonomy; Poland [Central Europe]; Swietokrzyskie; Swietokrzyskie Mountains; algae; Caulerpales; Dasycladales					2013/08/A/ST10/00717	"This project was financially supported by the NCN Maestro grant No. 2013/08/A/ST10/00717 . Wrzo?ek (University of Silesia) to whom we are also very thankful. Dr. S. LoDuca (Eastern Michigan University) is thanked for hints and critical remarks concerning algae identifications. Two anonymous referees are thanked for critical reviews, constructive comments and very useful remarks. "Lycopodiopsids and equisetopsids from the Triassic of Quebrada de los F?siles Formation, San Rafael Basin, Argentina"	2016	Geobios	49	3		167	176		ecoturel@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar		10.1016/j.geobios.2016.01.017	https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84974674513&doi=10.1016%2fj.geobios.2016.01.017&partnerID=40&md5=6a0f4bd2a87e92dd293674c8fbf0c36e	"Divisi?n Paleobot?nica, Museo de La Plata. Facultad de Ciencias Naturales y Museo, Universidad Nacional de La Plata, Pasaje Teruggi s/n, Paseo del Bosque, La Plata, Argentina, Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Cient?ficas y T?cnicas (CONICET), Buenos Aires, Argentina; Morel, E.M., Divisi?n Paleobot?nica, Museo de La Plata. Facultad de Ciencias Naturales y Museo, Universidad Nacional de La Plata, Pasaje Teruggi s/n, Paseo del Bosque, La Plata, Argentina, Comisi?n de Investigaciones Cient?ficas (CIC), La Plata, Argentina; Ganuza, D., Divisi?n Paleobot?nica, Museo de La Plata. Facultad de Ciencias Naturales y Museo, Universidad Nacional de La Plata, Pasaje Teruggi s/n, Paseo del Bosque, La Plata, Argentina"	"In the late 1960s, rests of a low-diversity flora dominated by the lycopsid Pleuromeia were reported. The specimens were recovered from a creek near San Rafael, Mendoza Province, western Argentina, in the lower section of the Puesto Viejo Group, the Quebrada de los F?siles Formation, considered as Early Triassic in age. Despite the importance of this flora with respect to the end-Permian mass extinction event, it was not yet described nor illustrated. Since then, the age of the Puesto Viejo Group has been revised and the Quebrada de los F?siles Formation is now considered to be early Middle Triassic. The fossil plants are here first described and interpreted. The most common element, Pleuromeia cf. sternbergii, a species known worldwide that characterizes the post-extinction flora recovery, is accompanied by sphenopsids such as Neocalamites and Equisetostachys, and an herbaceous lycopsid. This community grew up associated with transient water bodies in flood plain environments that developed under warm temperate, strongly seasonal climatic conditions. The landscape was stressed by volcanism, and the conjunction of these factors probably restricted the colonization and development of a full ecosystem, as happened worldwide after the end-Permian mass extinction. ? 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS."
